WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN FARMERS EAT?
A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

From Charles Agar
Name: John M. Goodale
Address: 423-6th St., Saskatoon
Birthplace: Saskatoon

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS
What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1926
Where did you set up housekeeping? 1.2 miles from Saskatoon
Where had you been living before that? Montana
For how many people did you prepare meals? An average of 8
How far was it to your nearest store? 1.2 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Occasionally
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
The necessities

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Champion
In what quantities did you buy it? 5 lbs. at a time
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? Around $2.50 a hundred
How much did you use graham flour? Occasionally
Whole wheat flour? Occasionally
Was flour milled locally? Yes
How far away? 1.2 miles
What year? 1926
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $1.25
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? Small quantity
Oats? Small quantity
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Sometimes
How did you grind it? In a grain grinder
